programme.title: Man on Wire
programme.desc: Drama documentary that details the preparation for and execution of one of the most daring stunts of all time. On 7 August 1974, Frenchman Philippe Petit took a tightrope walk between the Twin Towers of New York's World Trade Center, incurring the wrath of the authorities. His outrageous feat was dubbed by some "the artistic crime of the century".

programme.title: Motorway Patrol
programme.desc: Documentary following members of the New Zealand highway patrol as they witness some of the best and worst behaviour on the nation's motorways. The series is centred around the roads of Auckland, the country's largest urban area, and features motoring chaos including major traffic collisions, escaped animals and pedestrians on busy roads. There is also footage of drivers falling asleep at the wheel, overloaded vehicles and suspects caught with illegal substances - plus a host of excuses as the people pulled over try to persuade officers they have not done anything wrong.(n)

programme.title: Craig Charles: UFO Conspiracies
programme.desc: Craig and co-host Sarah Cruddas examine the Chicago O'Hare International Airport case of November 2006 - the sighting of a flying saucer hovering over a United Airlines airport gate. The incident was witnessed by multiple aviation professionals, pilots and passengers. The immediate aftermath of the event was captured in real time by audio recordings of communication between the airport's Air Traffic Control tower and airline staff, but the sighting was dismissed by the US government's Federal Aviation Administration as a weather phenomenon. Craig and Sarah talk to UFO investigator Robert Powell, who reveals the UFO punched a circular hole in the clouds as it departed upwards after hovering over the terminal. Craig and Sarah also learn astonishing details about how aviation authorities handled the incident.(n)

programme.title: Craig Charles: UFO Conspiracies
programme.desc: Craig and space journalist Sarah Cruddas turn their attention to reports of alien abductions, focusing on the case of Yorkshire policeman Alan Godfrey in November 1980. The duo examine Godfrey's claims he was confronted head-on by a diamond shaped craft hovering in the road as he was coming off his night shift. Alan believed he `lost" 25 minutes, during which time he was on board the craft being medically examined by small beings and a tall man with a beard.(n)

programme.desc: Professor Alice Roberts follows archaeologists as they unearth Britain's most spectacular iron-age grave, a chariot burial in East Yorkshire. The programme also follows two other archaeological digs, an Iron-Age hill fort found in North Wales, and the remains of six roundhouses on the bed of Loch Tay in Perthshire, Scotland.

programme.title: Rome's Bloodiest Dynasty: The First Emperor
programme.desc: Bettany Hughes focuses on the day in 32BC when Octavian stole the secret will of his most dangerous political rival, Mark Antony. It is a moment that casts a light on what it took to win in Roman politics, as the cunning, brilliant subterfuge required paved Octavian's path to power by undermining Antony's popularity and giving Octavian the crucial support of Rome's Senate and people in the civil war that followed. Dramatisations featuring Jack Morris, Nathan Dean Williams and Taniel Yusef bring the key moments to life.

programme.desc: Helen Skelton and Alex Langlands visit Sherwood Forest to learn more about the legend of Robin Hood - who may or may not have been real - and King John, who definitely was. programme.title: Legends of the Pharaohs: Secrets of the Pyramid Builders
programme.desc: In ancient Egypt, following the death of legendary pharaoh Khufu, the matter as to who would succeed the builder of the greatest pyramid in history arose. Egyptologists think that investigating the turmoil of the succession could solve one of ancient history's most enduring mysteries - the riddle of the Sphinx. This is a story of lies, betrayals and history's most enigmatic statue.

programme.title: Clash of the Gods
programme.desc: Experts investigate the origins of Medusa who according to Greek mythology, turned anyone who looked at her into stone, and explore whether the story is rooted in truth as they examine the real-world connection to human corpses.

programme.title: Walking Through History
programme.desc: Tony Robinson takes a four-day trek along the coastline between Plymouth in Devon and Falmouth, learning about the thriving smuggling trade in Cornwall during the late 18th century. The area's tiny secretive harbours, beaches and secluded coves were ideal for illicit imports such as tobacco and brandy, and the business was so huge it threatened the national economy. Along his route, visiting such beauty spots as Lantic Bay and Polperro, he encounters all sorts of reminders of the trade and meets descendants of those involved.

programme.title: Architects of Darkness
programme.desc: Documentary exploring the roots of Adolf Hitler and tracing the story of his life from the town of his birth to his final days.

programme.title: How the Nazis Lost the War
programme.desc: Documentary series detailing the collapse of Hitler's empire from the inside out, with insight from historians, sociologists and military strategists. The opening instalment looks at Germany's allyship with despots and dictators and explains how these mutual relationships were doomed from the start. Germany's choice of strange bedfellows would come back to haunt the nation, which would ultimately pay a high price for those decisions.

programme.title: WWI: The First Modern War
programme.desc: A look at the devastating development of chemical weapons, as well as how British troops killed 10,000 Germans with huge explosions at Messine Ridge.

programme.title: Deep Sea Detectives
programme.desc: Forensic engineers sift through evidence in a bid to reveal why British freighter the Derbyshire sank in 1980 during a typhoon in the South China Sea, killing all 44 people onboard. They ask whether it was a storm or a design fault that was to blame.

programme.desc: How the ancient Chinese civilisation laid the foundations for the modern mastery of wind and waves.

programme.title: Lost Cities of the Trojans
programme.desc: Archaeologists examine new evidence uncovered in Turkey that may reveal more about the notorious tale of the Trojans.

programme.title: The Curse of Civil War Gold: Diving Deeper
programme.desc: A century-old secret lures Kevin and the team back to Georgia, where new finds suggest there is more Civil War gold to be discovered.

programme.title: Ancient Aliens
programme.desc: When Spanish Conquistadors obliterated the historical record of the Maya in the 16th century, did they wipe out evidence that ancient people traveled to the Americas from all over the world - and in flying craft provided by extraterrestrial visitors? Here, experts investigate such apparently far-fetched suggestions.

programme.title: Ancient Aliens
programme.desc: Experts examine strange stone structures on New England and New York's landscapes, contemplating whether they offer clues of alien visitors to Earth.

programme.title: Hitler: Uncovering His Fatal Obsession
programme.desc: Part two of two. Adolf Hitler's penchant for barbarism and destruction, starting with his surprise Russian invasion and the anarchy that followed.

programme.title: Rome's Bloodiest Dynasty: The First Emperor
programme.desc: Bettany Hughes focuses on the day in 32BC when Octavian stole the secret will of his most dangerous political rival, Mark Antony. It is a moment that casts a light on what it took to win in Roman politics, as the cunning, brilliant subterfuge required paved Octavian's path to power by undermining Antony's popularity and giving Octavian the crucial support of Rome's Senate and people in the civil war that followed. Dramatisations featuring Jack Morris, Nathan Dean Williams and Taniel Yusef bring the key moments to life.

programme.title: KGB: The Sword and the Shield
programme.desc: This history of the KGB, as told through its veterans and its victims, continues by focusing on Nikita Khrushchev's attempts to limit the security service's power. The initiative did not last long and as the KGB bounced back, it struck gold with a mole at the top of the Central Intelligence Agency in the United States.

programme.title: Deadliest Warrior
programme.desc: Experts pit the legendary Native American leader Crazy Horse against the Mexican revolutionary general Pancho Villa.

programme.title: Mega Transports
programme.desc: A wind farm - over 2,000 tons of highly sensitive and valuable cargo - needs to get from Europe to Taiwan in Asia using one of the world's largest heavy lift vessels. A team has only 37 days for loading in two ports and travelling once around half of the globe. To be able to transport the entire cargo, the crew even has to build another level altogether - in the middle of the deck.(n)

programme.title: Shootout
programme.desc: The fierce battles fought when US Special Forces launched a five-year hunt for members of al-Qaida and the Taliban in the mountains of Afghanistan.(n)

programme.title: Shootout
programme.desc: Recreating the series of battles in 1968 known as the Tet offensive, which saw North Vietnamese troops join forces with Vietcong guerrillas to fight American troops in the Vietnam War. The tactical assaults are thought to have been a turning point in the conflict, leading to the eventual withdrawal of US forces.(n)

programme.title: Life After People
programme.desc: A look at how Marine Corps dogs would put their training to use in the absence of their masters, and experts estimate how the passage of time will threaten humanity's relics.(n)

programme.title: Lock N' Load with R Lee Ermey
programme.desc: Gunnery Sgt. R. Lee 'Gunny' Ermey, takes us on a unique journey as he traces the development of the shotgun.(n)

programme.title: Ancient Aliens
programme.desc: An analysis of ancient monuments, questioning what compelled man to move colossal stones long distances to assemble remarkably similar configurations in several locations around the world. Some people believe that extraterrestrials instructed these complex structures be built. Presented by Giorgio Tsoukalos.(n)

programme.title: Ancient Aliens
programme.desc: Investigations into the power of the number three in history, science and astronomy, and its possible links to extraterrestrial life.(n)

programme.title: Ancient Aliens
programme.sub-title: The Shamans. Aliens and Forbidden Islands
programme.desc: Investigating whether spiritual leaders known as shamans, who have healed and protected people throughout history really have contact with extraterrestrial realms.(n)

programme.title: Ancient Aliens
programme.sub-title: Alien Breeders. Aliens and Mysterious Mountains
programme.desc: Theorists ask whether a currently unidentified species represented in human DNA could be a result of breeding between man and alien in the distant past.(n)

programme.title: Ancient Aliens
programme.desc: Experts investigate remote ruins, mysterious caves and legendary mountain portals, asking if these alleged stargates have brought ancient aliens to Earth.(n)

programme.title: Lost Gold of World War II
programme.desc: With new evidence suggesting the location of a possible treasure vault beneath the waterfall, John is determined to find a way in, though Mother Nature is wreaking havoc on his plans. Information is revealed about the knife that was found.(n)

programme.title: Hunting Nazi Treasure
programme.desc: The team tracks loot stolen from the Jewish community in 1943, venturing into Corsica, Germany and South America.(n)

programme.title: Britain's Most Historic Towns
programme.desc: Alice Roberts tells the story of the Regency period by studying the history of Cheltenham, Britain's most Regency town. She attends a period society ball, investigates the rigid social hierarchy of the age and explores the Regency fondness for enemas. The penultimate episode of the series in which Alice Roberts studies one key period in history by delving into the secrets of a historic town that encapsulates the era, providing an accurate impression of what life was really like at key moments in the turbulent past.(n)

programme.title: Hitler's Gold
programme.desc: The series exploring the covert financial web spun by the Nazis continues. This episode explores how the Nazis' finances were affected by preparing for and fighting war in Europe.(n)

programme.title: The Black Death: Digging Up Britain's Past
programme.desc: Helen Skelton and Alex Langlands head to the village of Poulton in Cheshire to see a location where archaeologists have dug up nearly 1,000 human skeletons. The remains have revealed secrets about life during the Black Death, including signs of backbreaking agricultural work, poor nutrition and battles.(n)

programme.title: Digging for Britain
programme.desc: Professor Alice Roberts follows archaeologists as they unearth Britain's most spectacular iron-age grave, a chariot burial in East Yorkshire. The programme also follows two other archaeological digs, an Iron-Age hill fort found in North Wales, and the remains of six roundhouses on the bed of Loch Tay in Perthshire, Scotland.(n)

programme.desc: One ski trip and Andrew was hooked on the resort town of Big Sky, Montana. When he met his wife Christy during their residency in orthopaedic surgery, he knew one day his family would find a place there.

programme.title: Living Big Sky
programme.sub-title: LA Couple Gets Fresh Start in Southwest Montana
programme.desc: Benjamin Randall is looking to expand his ski business, and there's no better place to do it than in Big Sky Country. He and his girlfriend Megan are leaving southern California for a fresh start in southwest Montana.

programme.title: Living Big Sky
programme.desc: One ski trip is all it took to get Kevin Chartier hooked on the Montana lifestyle. His wife Jennifer soon joined in his enthusiasm for Big Sky Country, and they knew it would be the perfect place to raise their 2-year-old son, Santiago.

programme.title: Living Big Sky
programme.sub-title: Denver Couple Makes the Move to Missoula
programme.desc: James and Kim are leaving the city life for Montana's great outdoors. While James grew up in Montana, small town living might be a bit of an adjustment for his wife, Kim, a city girl born and bred.

programme.title: Living Big Sky
programme.sub-title: Young Family With Big Budget Searches for New Home Near Bozeman
programme.desc: Sacha and Chad have a baby on the way, and they're ready to move miles away from LA to raise their new family in Big Sky Country.

programme.title: Living Big Sky
programme.sub-title: Party of Five Family Sets Sights on Montana
programme.desc: Chris and Christy, along with their kids Gabriel, Skylar, and Madeline are looking for a change of pace from their lives in southern California. With help from their tumbleweed wrangling real estate agent, they'll soon be enjoying Montana's big sky.

programme.title: Living Big Sky
programme.sub-title: Palm Springs Couple Trade Desert Life for Missoula Mountains
programme.desc: Tyler Kirk is bringing his wife Maggie and baby Landry back to his Montana roots. They can't wait to take advantage of Big Sky Country's great outdoors and are narrowing their search to the Missoula area, near Tyler's family.

programme.title: Living Big Sky
programme.sub-title: Wisconsin Family Takes Snowmobile Clothing Biz to Bozeman
programme.desc: For Wisconsin natives Wendy and Travis, the decision to buy a second home in Montana meant more snow, and a perfect place to grow Wendy's burgeoning business in snow gear. And what better place than Montana to test her gear!

programme.title: Living Big Sky
programme.sub-title: Young Family Says Bye Bye to Brooklyn, Hello to Bozeman
programme.desc: City folks Neal and Valarie are saying bye-bye to Brooklyn, and hello to Bozeman. After visiting Neal's sister, they knew it was the perfect place to raise their two sons Dax and Emmett, away from the hustle and bustle of New York.

programme.title: Living Big Sky
programme.sub-title: Chicago Family Moves West to Montana
programme.desc: Native Montanan Lindsey has convinced her husband, Jim, to sell their condo in downtown Chicago and head west. Now that their son Connor is two, they want to move to a scenic area with plenty of opportunities for fishing, hiking and skiing.

programme.title: Living Big Sky
programme.sub-title: New Hampshire Family Searches for Home in Kalispell
programme.desc: Justin and Megan are trading in the ocean view of Dover for their own slice of paradise in Big Sky Country. Megan, a native of Missoula, traded in her cowboy boots and moved out east with Justin. Four years and two children later, they're heading back.

programme.title: Living Big Sky
programme.sub-title: Texas Natives Put Down Roots in Red Lodge
programme.desc: Newlyweds Ashley and Kent are throwing in the towel, packing up their North Dakota digs, and crossing the Montana state border. Wanting to start a family, this outdoorsy couple have their sights set on the quaint little town of Red Lodge.

programme.title: Lakefront Bargain Hunt
programme.desc: A Stevens Point, WI, couple with two young children is looking for a vacation home. The couple grew up visiting Nepco Lake and enjoy its pristine, secluded atmosphere and close proximity to their hometown.

programme.title: Lakefront Bargain Hunt
programme.sub-title: A Central Florida Pet Paradise in Highlands County
programme.desc: Jen is a wildlife biologist who moved to the Highlands County area of Florida for work a few years ago. She eventually moved away to Tampa but misses all the nature and lakes in the area. With help from her boyfriend Scott, she's moving back.

programme.title: Lakefront Bargain Hunt
programme.desc: Amber is eager to find place to spend more time with children and relax at Lake Wedowee.

programme.title: Lakefront Bargain Hunt
programme.desc: A family owns a boat that they love taking out on the secluded waters of Lake Greenwood. They currently store the boat a marina and would like to purchase dream home that comes with a dock of its own.

programme.title: Lakefront Bargain Hunt
programme.sub-title: Fishing for a Full-Time Home on Lake Ontario
programme.desc: A New York couple loves living in Rochester but wants to move their family closer to the water. After years of saving, they are finally ready to find a full-time home on Lake Ontario.

programme.title: Lakefront Bargain Hunt
programme.sub-title: Living Large on Lake Lakengren, Ohio
programme.desc: A St. Petersburg, FL, couple wants to spend more time with family up north, but they don't want to give up waterfront living. They've decided to look for a vacation home on Ohio's Lake Lakengren that has the potential for full-time living.

programme.title: Lakefront Bargain Hunt
programme.desc: Best friends from Greenville, SC, love spending time on nearby Lake Keowee. Because their families are extremely close, they decide to pool their money and buy a vacation home to share.

programme.title: Lakefront Bargain Hunt
programme.sub-title: The Allure of Lake Lure, North Carolina
programme.desc: Over the past several years Steven and Erin have traveled all around the country for work. It was easy in the beginning when their children Preston and Mason were young, but as the boys grew older, Steven and Erin realized it was time to settle down.

programme.title: Lakefront Bargain Hunt
programme.sub-title: Welcome Home to Weiss Lake, Alabama
programme.desc: After 20 years away, Sloan is returning to the lake he grew up on to purchase a home with his girlfriend, Krystal. Set in the foothills of the Appalachians, Weiss Lake offers a number of activities in and around the water and is a great place to relax.

programme.title: Lakefront Bargain Hunt
programme.sub-title: Searching for an Adirondack Escape in New York
programme.desc: A Syracuse, NY, family is looking for the perfect spot for family getaways along the shores of Star Lake in the Adirondack region. They enlist the help of a local real estate agent and set out to find a rustic sanctuary that's just right for them.

programme.title: Lakefront Bargain Hunt
programme.sub-title: Securing a Future on Lake Sinclair, Georgia
programme.desc: Nancy and Scott have worked toward a lakefront home their entire lives. Scott has had a job since he was twelve years old and Nancy, an immigrant from Argentina, worked her way up from housekeeper to business owner.

programme.title: Lakefront Bargain Hunt
programme.sub-title: A Life to Pursue on Tippecanoe Lake, Indiana
programme.desc: Kandi grew up in Warsaw, Indiana, and spent her summers vacationing along the nearby shores of Tippecanoe Lake with her family. After graduating college and securing a job in Warsaw, she moved back in with mom and dad in their full-time home on the lake.

programme.title: Lakefront Bargain Hunt
programme.sub-title: An Alabama Panorama on Smith Lake
programme.desc: Larry and Rene are from Lewisburg, Tennessee, and have two wonderful kids, Ryan and Curtis. Even though they own a boat, they currently live on a farm without much water nearby, but they've spent much time visiting Alabama's Smith Lake.

programme.title: Lakefront Bargain Hunt

programme.title: Lakefront Bargain Hunt

programme.title: Mexico Life
programme.sub-title: Searching for an Active Lifestyle in the Riviera Maya
programme.desc: Cathy first met Cory in Spanish class, and now more than thirty years later the couple is moving to a Spanish-speaking country. While the couple loves the summers at their home in Lake Tahoe, the winters have been too brutal.

programme.title: Mexico Life
programme.sub-title: A New Adventure in Puerto Aventuras

programme.title: Mexico Life
programme.sub-title: Two Foodies Find New Inspiration in Sayulita, Mexico

programme.title: Mexico Life
programme.sub-title: Modern vs. Traditional in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico
programme.desc: Randy and Erica have been together for more than a decade, and while their love is still very much alive, they're excited to reconnect in their dream location.

programme.title: Mexico Life
programme.sub-title: Soaking Up the Sun in Cabo
programme.desc: After years of living in humid and hectic Florida, Brian and Terry are ready to find a drier climate in Mexico. The couple needs a home for the whole family, which includes Terry's mom and their dogs.

programme.title: Hitler
programme.desc: Investigates Hitler's breathtaking rise from election defeat in 1928 to Germany's Messiah in 1933. Experts analyze his speeches, dissect his PR gift and interrogate the mind of a man who ruthlessly executes his closest comrade.

programme.title: Hitler
programme.desc: A look at the mind of a dictator as Hitler tightens his grip on Germany and turns his sights to conquest. Experts investigate the key skills that enabled him to turn the tables on Europe's foreign leaders.

programme.title: Hitler
programme.desc: A look at the first three decades of Adolf Hitler's life unveils what transformed a down-and-out Austrian into the undisputed leader of the Nazi Party. We reveal the truth behind Hitler's time serving in World War One.

programme.title: Hitler
programme.desc: Having bathed in adulation and success for a decade, Hitler reacts when the tide of war turns against him. As he struggles to stay in control, expert analysis reveals the darkest arts of his personality, driven by his beliefs.

programme.title: Hitler
programme.desc: The final episode explores Hitler's mental and physical decline as he is forced to confront the endgame of inevitable defeat. When Hitler miraculously survives an assassination attempt, his lust for vengeance triggers an unequalled reign of terror.

programme.title: What History Forgot
programme.desc: We've all heard about the fallout shelters used for refuge during World War II, the deadly firebombing of Tokyo, and the D-Day invasion on the beaches of Normandy but there are more secrets.

programme.title: What History Forgot
programme.desc: Rosa parks was not the first African American women to refuse to give up her seat. The Berlin Airlift included candy for kids. One of the great rifles used in war was invented by a man who made moonshine.

programme.title: Apocalypse: World War One
programme.desc: On June 28, 1914, the assassination of an obscure Austrian archduke in Sarajevo triggers the most disastrous conflict the world has ever known. Germany becomes an enemy to France, invades Belgium and, in September, arrives at the gates of Paris.

programme.title: Apocalypse: World War One
programme.desc: The French Army stops the German advance at the battle of the Marne while the Germans halt the Russians at the Tannenberg on the eastern front.

programme.title: Apocalypse: World War One
programme.desc: War descends into hell. The battlefield becomes a slaughterhouse. After 16 months of fighting, five million men are dead. Despite this, neither side has gained any ground until a new and terrifying machine rolls onto the battlefield: the tank.

programme.title: Apocalypse: World War One
programme.desc: People have had enough of the war and uprisings are brewing. German submarine attacks provoke the Americans, but they arrive too late to prevent the Battle of Passchendaele.

programme.title: Apocalypse: World War One
programme.desc: All seems lost for the Allies. The Italians are defeated at Caporette, and a Bolshevik Russia pulls out of the war. But the American reinforcements are decisive, and the Allies emerge victorious.

programme.title: Weaponology
programme.desc: Artillery is ever present on the battlefield, and always evolving to keep pace with warfare. From catapults to cannons, ballista to battleships, gunpowder to giant super guns, chart the evolution of this powerful dynasty of destruction.

programme.title: Deadliest Tech
programme.desc: Explosives are the terrifying sound and fury of modern warfare, annihilating any military target that threatens an army's personnel or stands in their way.

programme.title: Deadliest Tech

programme.title: Weaponology

programme.desc: Hitler's bid for power depends on his most loyal, and violent supporters: the SS. Using surveillance, detention, and even murder, they defeat political enemies and are most responsible for putting Hitler's deadly policy of racial purity into practice.

programme.title: Blood and Fury: America's Civil War

programme.title: Blood and Fury: America's Civil War

programme.title: Blood and Fury: America's Civil War

programme.title: Blood and Fury: America's Civil War

programme.title: Blood and Fury: America's Civil War
programme.desc: In a daring attempt to regain the upper hand in the Civil War, Confederate forces try to retake the city of Nashville and sever the supply line that's feeding the Union invasion of the south.

programme.title: Blood and Fury: America's Civil War

programme.title: Secrets of the Arsenal

programme.title: What History Forgot
programme.sub-title: To the Ends of the World

programme.title: What History Forgot

programme.title: What History Forgot
programme.desc: We all know of George Washington, the California Gold Rush, the vast highways that stretch across America, and the wars between the United States and Great Britain. Learn about the secrets behind the making of America.

programme.title: Hitler's Empire: The Post-War Plan
programme.desc: In this episode, we'll see how Hitler used the Olympic games to promote Nazism. How he controlled the leisure time and holidays of his Citizens by developing the world's largest travel agency. And how by constructing the world's biggest beach resort.

programme.title: Apocalypse: Hitler
programme.desc: See how Hitler succeeded in conquering Germany. Nothing predestines this mediocre student and failed artist to become dictator of Germany the Führer.

programme.title: Apocalypse: Hitler

programme.title: I (Almost) Got Away With It

programme.desc: After getting arrested for robbery, Robert Askew runs from a work camp and goes back to stealing to make a living. Askew eventually gets caught again, but he escapes from jail during a hurricane and goes on a crime spree, breaking into vacation homes.

programme.title: I (Almost) Got Away With It
programme.sub-title: Got to Wear a Pink Shirt
programme.desc: Abraham Cavazos shot a man at a party and fled to Mexico, where multiple women supported him. Although he changed identities, locations and girlfriends, the authorities found him.

programme.title: I (Almost) Got Away With It
programme.desc: When a friend is fired from a restaurant, Konh Chung Bounnam and his friends decide to rob it. The plan goes awry and three people are killed. His friends are caught but Bounnam stays free. He hides until his need for money gets the FBI's attention.

programme.title: I (Almost) Got Away With It
programme.sub-title: Got to Run With My Brother

programme.title: Patriots Rising: The American Revolution

programme.title: Patriots Rising: The American Revolution

programme.title: Project Nazi: The Blueprints of Evil

programme.title: Project Nazi: The Blueprints of Evil

programme.title: Waco StandoffAs We Watched
programme.desc: On April 19, 1993, FBI agents attacked a religious compound in Waco, Texas, occupied by a small obscure religious cult. 76 people, including 26 children, died. The repercussions of Waco are still being felt.

programme.title: Hitler's Empire: The Post-War Plan
programme.desc: In this episode we'll examine how the Nazis began to stamp their image on Germany and the nations that had fallen under the German jackboot. From plans to redesign Berlin as the capital of the world, to the destruction of Warsaw.(n)

programme.title: Hitler's Empire: The Post-War Plan
programme.desc: In this episode we'll uncover support for the National Socialist movement within America, revealing outposts of Nazi Germany within the land of the free. We'll also learn about the man thought he believed he was the American Fuhrer.(n)

programme.title: Hitler
programme.desc: A look at the mind of a dictator as Hitler tightens his grip on Germany and turns his sights to conquest. Experts investigate the key skills that enabled him to turn the tables on Europe's foreign leaders.(n)

programme.title: Hitler
programme.desc: The final episode explores Hitler's mental and physical decline as he is forced to confront the endgame of inevitable defeat. When Hitler miraculously survives an assassination attempt, his lust for vengeance triggers an unequalled reign of terror.(n)

programme.title: Wild and Wonderful Denmark
programme.desc: Dive into the sea around Denmark and meet the creatures that live there. We spot the anglerfish that camouflages itself on the ocean floor.

programme.title: Wild Arabia
programme.desc: Exploring the mountains of Dhofar in Oman, where the annual Indian Ocean monsoon has helped create a lost world of waterfalls and cloud forests filled with fascinating wildlife. The programme shows green sea turtles coming ashore in their thousands, shadowed by egg-stealing foxes, as well as footage of striped hyenas doing battle with Arabian wolves. Plus, a glimpse into the lives of chameleons, honey badgers and the elusive Arabian leopard.

programme.title: The Zoo
programme.desc: Helen takes a trip to the Republic of the Congo, venturing into the country's swamps and rainforests to visit a project supported by Dublin Zoo. Zookeeper Yvonne does some charity work with Hedgehog Rescue Dublin, and the Asian leaf turtle habitat is redecorated.

programme.title: The Zoo
programme.desc: Zookeepers Ken and John say goodbye to Jubari the rhino, who they have cared for since he was a young calf, as he is now old enough to start a herd of his own.

programme.title: Bahama Blue
programme.desc: Looking at the diverse and colourful marine creatures as they live among the coral structures and share the reef under the water.

programme.title: Bahama Blue
programme.desc: Looking at the diverse and colourful marine creatures as they live among the coral structures and share the reef under the water.

programme.title: Collar of Duty
programme.sub-title: Steve & Tahoe/ Manny & Captain Jack Sparrow
programme.desc: A military veteran with PTSD receives therapy involving a horse that allows him to be free of his painful memories, and a dog provides support to a paraplegic man.

programme.title: Teleshopping
programme.desc: A chance to buy goods from the comfort of home.

programme.title: The Zoo
programme.desc: The elephants enjoy a mud bath and the red pandas meet up as the documentary following life at Dublin Zoo continues.

programme.title: The Zoo
programme.desc: The African painted dog habitat welcomes some new arrivals, with a trio of male dogs joining the all-female pack. A tiger undergoes emergency dental surgery, and Garth leaves the city for a trip into the countryside, when he visits a conservation project that protects lapwing chicks.

programme.title: Life in the Air
programme.desc: The final episode of the series features footage shot from within a giant flock of birds, revealing how half a million of them can fly in a group without colliding with each other. The programme also showcases the world's fastest airborne courtship display, a bird that savagely defends its territory, and conflict between moths and bats in the South American jungle.

programme.title: Natural World
programme.desc: Bill Bailey narrates this natural history documentary telling the story of some of nature's most extraordinary partnerships, revealing what sometimes happens when animals need an itch scratching, help getting into food or home security assistance. The answer is, to find a partner - and not necessarily one of the same species. Highlights include hippos joining forces with fish for a full-body exfoliation and ravens inviting wolverines over for some bone-crunching assistance with their dinner.

programme.title: Blue Planet II
programme.desc: Creatures that live in volcanic hot spots on the ocean bed, areas that reach temperatures hot enough to melt lead and which may hold the secrets behind all life on Earth. Other strange creatures from the depths of the sea include bone-eating worms, fish that walk rather than swim, and hordes of squid. Plus, footage of sharks in a feeding frenzy over the dead body of a whale and the wildlife of the Midnight Zone in the Pacific, an area that never receives any natural light, forcing creatures to rely on their own bioluminescence.

programme.title: Blue Planet II
programme.desc: Creatures that live on coral reefs, including groupers, small predators that scientists believe are as intelligent as chimpanzees. These creatures have a remarkable aptitude for communication to the point where they can interact with other species including octopi and work together to catch prey. Plus, footage of a vast spawning event involving several different species of fish, coral and invertebrates, and time-lapse photography of coral polyps growing and dying, creating a structure visible from space.

programme.title: Life in the Air
programme.desc: The final episode of the series features footage shot from within a giant flock of birds, revealing how half a million of them can fly in a group without colliding with each other. The programme also showcases the world's fastest airborne courtship display, a bird that savagely defends its territory, and conflict between moths and bats in the South American jungle.

programme.title: Galapagos
programme.desc: High-definition cameras and aerial photography techniques are used to explore the archipelago, which is rich in wildlife and made famous by Charles Darwin's On the Origin of the Species. This programme focuses on the geological history of the islands through the evidence of volcanic eruptions and examines what makes it unique. Tilda Swinton narrates.

programme.title: Galapagos
programme.desc: Examining the lesser-known parts of the islands and the species that have successfully evolved to suit the environment. The programme discovers how tortoise shells have changed shape, flowers have turned yellow to attract bees, and finches have become warblers. Plus, how flightless cormorants are still hunting underwater. Narrated by Tilda Swinton.

programme.title: Wild and Wonderful Denmark
programme.desc: In the last episode of the series, we witness how some animals adapt to urban conditions, like when crows drop walnuts on streets in order to leave the nut-cracking to the cars.

programme.title: Wild Arabia
programme.desc: The changes that have swept across the Arabian peninsula since the discovery of oil. Camel racing has become a hi-tech sport and the region's animals now live alongside a very modern society, but technology is also being used to protect nature. The programme reveals how dugongs are fitted with satellite transmitters and hunting falcons chase down radio-controlled planes, and follows the construction of the world's first carbon-neutral city. Narrated by Alexander Siddig.

programme.title: The Zoo
programme.desc: The elephants enjoy a mud bath and the red pandas meet up as the documentary following life at Dublin Zoo continues.

programme.title: The Zoo

programme.title: Bahama Blue
programme.desc: Looking at species including Oceanic whitetip sharks, sperm whales and Blainesville's beaked whales as they survive in the open water in the Bahamas.

programme.title: Bahama Blue
programme.desc: Looking at how the interconnected ecosystems and species in the Bahamas depend on each other in order to survive.

programme.title: Collar of Duty
programme.desc: A war veteran diagnosed with PTSD finds solace in two rescue parrots, while an English Spaniel diabetic alert dog detects Noah's life-threatening drops in blood sugar levels.

programme.title: Teleshopping
programme.desc: A chance to buy goods from the comfort of home.

programme.title: The Zoo
programme.desc: An Asian lion cub has an injured leg, and an X-ray is needed to determine if it has any broken bones. A female scimitar-horned oryx joins the zoo's herd, and hopes are high that it will mate with the dominant male. Keeper Brendan Price pays a visit to Dublin's Natural History Museum to discuss primates.

programme.title: The Zoo
programme.desc: There is excitement in the gorilla enclosure as a pregnant female draws closer to giving birth, but this is tempered by the news that a male silverback has fallen ill. The orang-utans venture into their new habitat, which they have to share with the boisterous siamang gibbons.

programme.title: Attenborough's Passion Project
programme.sub-title: Charles Darwin & The Tree of Life
programme.desc: In a documentary originally broadcast in 2009, to mark the bicentenary of Charles Darwin's birth, David Attenborough shares his views on the naturalist's theory of evolution, revealing why he believes it is now more important than ever before. He considers how Darwin reached his conclusions and the way major scientific discoveries have helped underpin and strengthen them since the publication of On the Origin of Species more than 150 years ago.

programme.title: Jaguars: Brazil's Super Cats: Natural World
programme.sub-title: Natural World: Jaguars - Brazil's Super Cats
programme.desc: Documentary following a pioneering team in Brazil as they track individual wild jaguars in order to gain new insights into their lives. However, when two young cubs are orphaned, the team must use its new-found knowledge to help them return to the wild.

programme.title: Blue Planet II
programme.desc: Creatures that live on coral reefs, including groupers, small predators that scientists believe are as intelligent as chimpanzees. These creatures have a remarkable aptitude for communication to the point where they can interact with other species including octopi and work together to catch prey. Plus, footage of a vast spawning event involving several different species of fish, coral and invertebrates, and time-lapse photography of coral polyps growing and dying, creating a structure visible from space.

programme.title: Blue Planet II
programme.desc: Wildlife that live thousands of kilometres from land, featuring footage of baby turtles using debris as life rafts and whales sharks embarking on lengthy voyages across the Pacific to the point where it is safest to give birth. Special pressure-proof cameras are used to film sperm whales hunting for squid a kilometre beneath the surface and the impact of plastic pollution on the oceans is revealed.

programme.title: Galapagos
programme.desc: Examining the lesser-known parts of the islands and the species that have successfully evolved to suit the environment. The programme discovers how tortoise shells have changed shape, flowers have turned yellow to attract bees, and finches have become warblers. Plus, how flightless cormorants are still hunting underwater. Narrated by Tilda Swinton.

programme.title: Galapagos
programme.desc: An insight into how creatures adapt to the islands' extremes of weather, including iguanas that climb more than 1,000 metres to lay eggs, fish forced to rely on the shade provided by mangroves, and seals that survive on exposed shorelines by taking shelter in lava grottos.

programme.title: Attenborough's Passion Project
programme.sub-title: Charles Darwin & The Tree of Life
programme.desc: In a documentary originally broadcast in 2009, to mark the bicentenary of Charles Darwin's birth, David Attenborough shares his views on the naturalist's theory of evolution, revealing why he believes it is now more important than ever before. He considers how Darwin reached his conclusions and the way major scientific discoveries have helped underpin and strengthen them since the publication of On the Origin of Species more than 150 years ago.

programme.title: Blue Planet II
programme.desc: Wildlife that live thousands of kilometres from land, featuring footage of baby turtles using debris as life rafts and whales sharks embarking on lengthy voyages across the Pacific to the point where it is safest to give birth. Special pressure-proof cameras are used to film sperm whales hunting for squid a kilometre beneath the surface and the impact of plastic pollution on the oceans is revealed.

programme.title: The Zoo
programme.desc: An Asian lion cub has an injured leg, and an X-ray is needed to determine if it has any broken bones. A female scimitar-horned oryx joins the zoo's herd, and hopes are high that it will mate with the dominant male. Keeper Brendan Price pays a visit to Dublin's Natural History Museum to discuss primates.

programme.title: The Zoo
programme.desc: There is excitement in the gorilla enclosure as a pregnant female draws closer to giving birth, but this is tempered by the news that a male silverback has fallen ill. The orang-utans venture into their new habitat, which they have to share with the boisterous siamang gibbons.

programme.title: Jaguars: Brazil's Super Cats: Natural World
programme.sub-title: Natural World: Jaguars - Brazil's Super Cats
programme.desc: Documentary following a pioneering team in Brazil as they track individual wild jaguars in order to gain new insights into their lives. However, when two young cubs are orphaned, the team must use its new-found knowledge to help them return to the wild.

programme.title: Galapagos
programme.desc: An insight into how creatures adapt to the islands' extremes of weather, including iguanas that climb more than 1,000 metres to lay eggs, fish forced to rely on the shade provided by mangroves, and seals that survive on exposed shorelines by taking shelter in lava grottos.

programme.sub-title: Charles Darwin & The Tree of Life

programme.desc: There is excitement in the gorilla enclosure as a pregnant female draws closer to giving birth, but this is tempered by the news that a male silverback has fallen ill. The orang-utans venture into their new habitat, which they have to share with the boisterous siamang gibbons.

programme.title: Wild Africa
programme.desc: Fergal Keane narrates a documentary focusing on the abundant wildlife found along the continent's 29,000km coastline. Species exist in habitats as diverse as the icy waters of the Cape and the tropical climes of the Indian Ocean, leading to some bizarre variations in behaviour - seals eat birds and die of heatstroke, crabs climb trees and penguins live in deserts.

programme.title: Ganges
programme.desc: The final leg of the river's journey sees it join its tributary the Brahmaputra. As the waters merge, they overspill their banks to fan out into hundreds of smaller rivulets and create the world's largest delta. The programme reveals how people and wildlife survive the inhospitable habitat, perhaps the last place on Earth where the Bengal tiger is still king.

programme.title: The Zoo
programme.desc: An Asian lion cub has an injured leg, and an X-ray is needed to determine if it has any broken bones. A female scimitar-horned oryx joins the zoo's herd, and hopes are high that it will mate with the dominant male. Keeper Brendan Price pays a visit to Dublin's Natural History Museum to discuss primates.

programme.title: The Zoo
programme.desc: There is excitement in the gorilla enclosure as a pregnant female draws closer to giving birth, but this is tempered by the news that a male silverback has fallen ill. The orang-utans venture into their new habitat, which they have to share with the boisterous siamang gibbons.

programme.title: Life in the Great Wetlands
programme.desc: Documentary series exploring wildlife that live in wetlands, beginning with the flooded zones of Gabon's Loango National Park, home to elephants, hippopotamuses and gorillas.

programme.title: Life in the Great Wetlands
programme.desc: Kinabatangan in the Sabah region of East Malaysia provides a sanctuary for several endangered species, whose habitats are surrounded by logging operations and plantations.

programme.title: Collar of Duty
programme.desc: A black Labrador helps a bright young boy with autism gain independence and engage in social activities, and a photographer with PTSD is helped by a deaf American Bulldog.

programme.title: Teleshopping
programme.desc: A chance to buy goods from the comfort of home.

programme.title: The Zoo
programme.desc: Sari the Bornean orang-utan is soon to be leaving her home at Barcelona Zoo to join Sibu and the rest of the troop in Dublin. As part of an international study dubbed tinder for orangutans, the zookeepers use a video introduction to help break the ice. Asha was the very first Asian elephant to be born at Dublin Zoo's Elephant House, and 10 years one, she's ready to give birth to a calf of her own after a 22-month pregnancy.

programme.title: The Zoo
programme.desc: Two hand-reared gorillas are integrated into the troop, the keepers await the birth of a southern white rhinoceros, and Susan investigates threats to barn owls in Co Kerry.

programme.title: Natural World
programme.desc: The remarkable story of Sudan, the very last male northern white rhino on the planet. Snatched from his mother's side in Central Africa, Sudan became a prized exhibit in a zoo while the rest of his kind were poached to near-extinction. This programme focuses on the desperate battle to bring his sub-species back from the brink of extinction, told through the characters who have been involved in his life.

programme.title: Natural World
programme.desc: For animals growing up is a real adventure, but finding food, avoiding predators and making friends doesn't always come naturally, so they need a little parental guidance to help them learn and hone the skills that will enable them to survive on their own. David Tennant narrates this documentary following the trials and tribulations of young animals all over the world as they prepare to leave home.

programme.title: Blue Planet II
programme.desc: Wildlife that live thousands of kilometres from land, featuring footage of baby turtles using debris as life rafts and whales sharks embarking on lengthy voyages across the Pacific to the point where it is safest to give birth. Special pressure-proof cameras are used to film sperm whales hunting for squid a kilometre beneath the surface and the impact of plastic pollution on the oceans is revealed.

programme.title: Blue Planet II
programme.desc: Footage of wildlife inhabiting underwater kelp forests, including thousands of giant cuttlefish spawning along a restricted area of rocky reef off the south coast of Australia. Males outnumber females 11 to one, which leads to fierce competition. Larger males use brute force to drive off competition, while their smaller rivals use deception by mimicking the appearance of females. The programme also features tiger sharks hunting for green turtles in fields of seagrass and spider crabs trying to avoid predators while they shed their shells.

programme.title: Natural World

Snatched from his mother's side in Central Africa, Sudan became a prized exhibit in a zoo while the rest of his kind were poached to near-extinction. David Tennant narrates this documentary following the trials and tribulations of young animals all over the world as they prepare to leave home.

programme.title: Yellowstone
programme.desc: Following the wildlife that inhabits the famous American national park, a lost world of deep forests, vast plains and bubbling geysers. The first episode focuses on a variety of species as they struggle to survive the rigours of a freezing six-month winter, revealing that although the herds of elk and bison are weakened by the cold, one animal gets stronger - the wolf.

programme.title: The Zoo
programme.desc: Two hand-reared gorillas are integrated into the troop, the keepers await the birth of a southern white rhinoceros, and Susan investigates threats to barn owls in Co Kerry.

programme.title: Bahama Blue
programme.desc: Looking at species including Oceanic whitetip sharks, sperm whales and Blainesville's beaked whales as they survive in the open water in the Bahamas.

programme.title: Bahama Blue
programme.desc: Looking at how the interconnected ecosystems and species in the Bahamas depend on each other in order to survive.

programme.title: Collar of Duty
programme.desc: A golden doodle named Hope helps an ex-military mum cope with her PTSD - and other serious physical ailments - so that she can be the mother she wants to be again.

programme.title: Teleshopping
programme.desc: A chance to buy goods from the comfort of home.

programme.title: Equator: The Line of Life
programme.desc: Rainforests on the Equator hold the greatest biodiversity on Earth. We meet gorillas in Africa learning to befriend people, and travel to Ecuador on a search for jaguars.

programme.title: Equator: The Line of Life
programme.desc: Discover the conflict between animals, farmers, and the conservationists that stand between them. In Indonesia, elephants are saved from slaughter by a young female mahout.

programme.title: Equator: The Line of Life
programme.desc: In the Equatorial waters, there's such a thing as too much heat. In the Maldives, the ravages of global warming are being repaired by incredibly inventive 'coral doctors'.

programme.title: Blue Planet II
programme.desc: Footage of wildlife inhabiting underwater kelp forests, including thousands of giant cuttlefish spawning along a restricted area of rocky reef off the south coast of Australia. Males outnumber females 11 to one, which leads to fierce competition. Larger males use brute force to drive off competition, while their smaller rivals use deception by mimicking the appearance of females. The programme also features tiger sharks hunting for green turtles in fields of seagrass and spider crabs trying to avoid predators while they shed their shells.

programme.title: Ganges
programme.desc: Exploring the story of the river, following its course from the Himalayas to their foothills. The programme reveals its enormous influence on the day-to-day living of a continent, how it has shaped Indian culture and religion and why it attracts a vast array of wildlife including snow leopards, Asiatic brown bears and bearded vultures.

programme.title: Horizon
programme.desc: Although oceans define the earth and are crucial to life, recent discoveries have revealed that they are not unique to earth. Oceans have been located across the solar system, and scientists are now embarking on a journey in search of new life in places that never seemed possible. With Nasa planning to dive to the depths of a strange, distant ocean in a remarkable submarine, the programme discovers that the hunt for oceans in space is marking the dawn of a new era in the search for alien life.

programme.title: Earth: The Power of the Planet
programme.desc: Dr Iain Stewart investigates the powerful natural forces that shaped the planet over billions of years. Starting with volcanos, he abseils to the edge of an Ethiopian lava lake and explores the underwater caverns believed to have been created by the meteor that wiped out the dinosaurs. The presenter also explains the positive role played by the greenhouse effect many millennia ago in ending the last ice age.

programme.title: Earth: The Power of the Planet
programme.desc: Dr Iain Stewart examines Earth's unique atmosphere, revealing how it was initially made up of noxious volcanic gases until the emergence of life forms gave the planet oxygen. He also visits Argentina to explain how the atmosphere affects the weather - and almost loses his eyebrows during an experiment designed to demonstrate how methane is escaping through the permafrost in Siberia.

programme.title: Earth: The Power of the Planet
programme.desc: Dr Iain Stewart examines the role of ice in changing the course of human evolution and shaping the planet's landscape, visiting a frozen waterfall, a unique lab in Arctic Norway and the granite peaks of Yosemite to learn more about the phenomenal power of glaciers. He also travels to Greenland to examine the evidence of climate change, and asks what the consequences will be if Earth's ice continues to melt.

programme.title: Earth: The Power of the Planet
programme.desc: Dr Iain Stewart examines the role of oceans in the formation of Earth as it is today. From the shaping of coastlines to the phenomenon of El Nino, the energy of the current is the most consistent in nature and when it fails the effects are catastrophic. Investigating what will happen if global warming proceeds as predicted, the presenter discovers carbon dioxide will acidify and destroy many nutrients. When last that happened, 250 million years ago, it led to the biggest mass extinction in history.

programme.title: Earth: The Power of the Planet
programme.desc: Dr Iain Stewart looks at Earth's place in time and space. By examining the destruction of species and the fall of empires, he demonstrates the strength of the planet in comparison with human vulnerability. The biggest factors in this protection are Earth's unique position in the solar system, protected by the gravitational pull of the larger Jupiter, with the moon providing stability. By studying Mars, he shows just how lucky mankind has been.

programme.title: 24 Hours on Earth
programme.desc: Documentary revealing how the changing position of the sun over the course of a day affects the behaviour of animals and plants across the planet. From the moment it rises, animals are waiting, ready to take advantage of the opportunities that the sun creates, from the chameleon that uses solar power to survive to a family of lemurs enjoying the early morning heat. However, sunlight also plunges creatures into crisis, as for some the height of the day is the most dangerous time.

programme.title: Collar of Duty
programme.desc: In Berkeley, California, a college student fights depression with the help of a rescue pigeon named Miu. An inspirational surfing dog named Ricochet, helps an autistic youngster.(n)

programme.desc: A chance to buy goods from the comfort of home.(n)

programme.title: The Blue Planet
programme.desc: Marine life at the poles, where winter temperatures frequently fall to a numbing -40C. Even when the sun reappears in the spring, its weak rays take a long time to melt the ice. David Attenborough describes how wildlife including seals, whales, polar bears and penguins overcome the elements to survive through prolonged cold spells.(n)

programme.title: The Blue Planet
programme.desc: An exploration of the world's most densely inhabited waters, where variations in temperature owing to the year-long cycle of the sun encourage a vast array of marine life, from seals and sharks in the winter, to lobster and salmon in the summer, dolphins in the autumn and the walking handfish in spring. Narrated by David Attenborough.(n)

programme.title: The Blue Planet
programme.desc: Veteran naturalist David Attenborough explores the fragile marine ecosystem of the coral reef, where all creatures, including the corals themselves, have to fight for survival. From tiny beginnings, the reef grows and develops over hundreds of years, providing support for innumerable animals - yet one storm can threaten the entire community.(n)

programme.title: The Blue Planet
programme.desc: David Attenborough investigates the opportunities tides create for marine life, showing giant stingrays gliding on currents for a rest, South African sea snails surfing the waves in pursuit of a meal, crabs playing football on a beach, and bottlenose dolphins embarking on a dangerous game of catch. In the oceanic world each turn of the tide can mean life or death for its inhabitants.(n)

programme.title: Life in the Undergrowth
programme.desc: David Attenborough turns his attention to the network of partnerships that invertebrates have developed with one another and with plants. He reveals how the fairy wasp, the world's smallest insect, flies underwater to inject its eggs into those of the water beetle. Footage also shows how the caterpillar of the blue butterfly smuggles its way into an ants' nest by mimicking the smell of their young.(n)

programme.title: Life in the Undergrowth
programme.desc: David Attenborough explores how insects compensate for their small size by banding together in vast numbers. He reveals that the operations of many of these societies are so finely tuned they appear to work as a single entity. Footage shows how African termite mounds act as huge ventilation systems of such sophistication that humans are only now beginning to unravel the mechanics of the structure.(n)

programme.title: Cool DaddyThe Kenny Colman Story
programme.desc: Chase, son of jazz singer Kenny Colman, tries his hand at singing in an attempt to reconcile with his ailing father.

programme.title: Still Standing
programme.desc: Jonny visits Harrison Hot Springs, BC, a town doubling down on creating a year round economy outside the resort, and hopes their other claim to fame, the elusive Sasquatch, will be the ticket.

programme.title: Indigenous Dads
programme.desc: Four indigenous fathers from differing cultural backgrounds and life experiences discuss their roles as fathers.

programme.title: Rise of the Nazis
programme.desc: At the peak of his power, Hitler now faces fellow ruthless dictator Stalin. He tries to deceive Stalin with a plan to invade Britain, all while preparing an attack on the Soviet Union.

programme.title: Rise of the Nazis
programme.desc: The Nazis have lost in Moscow. Hitler and Stalin take charge of their armies - with no-one to hold them back. In Stalin, Hitler has met his match - it's now a fight to the death.

programme.title: Rise of the Nazis
programme.desc: Facing defeat on the Eastern Front, Hitler retreats. Deep rifts emerge, and his inner circle vies for power. The resistance gets a student voice, and an enemy within plots to kill Hitler.

programme.title: Himalaya with Michael Palin
programme.desc: Following his adventures at Everest Base Camp, the intrepid traveller leaves the mountains behind and moves on to Tibet. Here he discovers that, while there may be an increasing Chinese influence, religion is once again being tolerated. He visits the Potala Palace, the spectacular monasteries of Tashilunpo and takes a dip in a hot spring. From there he continues his journey with a family of nomads heading to a summer horse festival in Yushu.

programme.title: Himalaya with Michael Palin
programme.desc: The adventurer travels along the Yangtze river into China, where he meets Mosuo singer Namu, who explains the region's traditional walking marriage ceremonies. He continues into India to marvel at one of Assam's great tea estates, makes the acquaintance of the local elephants and stays at a monastery where the monks introduce him to their unique dancing style.

programme.title: Teleshopping
programme.desc: A chance to buy goods from the comfort of home.

programme.title: Himalaya with Michael Palin
programme.sub-title: Bhutan to the Bay of Bengal
programme.desc: Michael's journey takes him to Bhutan, where he enjoys a last glimpse of the Himalaya before heading to Paro to enjoy a Buddhist festival. Here he witnesses archery contests and the unfolding of a giant scroll during the night of a full moon.

programme.title: Michael Palin's New Europe
programme.desc: The veteran traveller visits Croatia, Bosnia and Serbia, witnessing the effects of the massive economic changes that have taken place since the fall of communism. He also sails to Albania with an opera-singing captain and finds out how the once ultra-secretive country is becoming more open.

programme.title: Churchill's Bodyguard
programme.desc: Documentary series based upon the memoirs of the wartime PM's bodyguard. Churchill falls ill and stops breathing. With no doctor around it is left to Walter Thompson - no expert in medical matters - to save his life.

programme.title: War Factories
programme.desc: Focusing on the mass production of ammunition brought on by Samuel Colt, and the inadequacy of Soviet factory production which made the AK47 so effective.

programme.title: Abandoned Engineering
programme.desc: A now-silent site that played a pivotal role defending the USA through the 20th century. Plus, a crumbling Italian fortress and a ghostly Ukrainian mansion.

programme.title: Abandoned Engineering
programme.desc: A juggernaut of Soviet engineering which was crucial to the international space race. Deserted Scottish coastal defences and a complex that's crucial to American history.

programme.title: The Architecture the Railways Built
programme.desc: Tim Dunn visits the Ffestiniog in North Wales originally built to transport slate from mountain to coast and learns about Amsterdam Centraal.

programme.title: Chris Tarrant: Extreme Railways
programme.desc: Chris attempts to cross the length of Cuba, the only island in the Caribbean to boast an extensive railway network, starting in Havana in the west. This proves to be a major challenge given the unreliability of the service and the old trains regularly used, but makes for a fascinating journey to Chris's ultimate goal, the American naval base at Guantanamo Bay. Along the way he soaks up the sights and sounds of Havana, retraces the footsteps of the country's national hero Che Guevara, and visits the ghost town of Camilo Cienfuegos - a relic from Cuba's colonial sugar plantation era.

programme.title: Abandoned Engineering
programme.desc: Series exploring ruined engineering projects that have been put to alternative use, including the site of the Chernobyl disaster and a Nazi holiday complex.

programme.title: Abandoned Engineering
programme.desc: Abandoned projects of the space age, including the HARP gun in Barbados and the mountainside Barcroft Observatory in California.

programme.title: Churchill's Bodyguard
programme.desc: Churchill and Thompson visit Greece, where communists conspire to detonate a 1,000lb bomb in the sewers beneath the road on the Prime Minister's designated route. When this fails, they shoot at his plane and try to sink his ship HMS Ajax.

programme.title: War Factories
programme.desc: The First World War led to a number of astounding war factories, which laid the foundations and paved the way for modern factories of today.

programme.title: Chris Tarrant: Extreme Railways
programme.desc: Chris journeys a thousand miles across Japan, starting out in Nagasaki, where the story of eastern railways began 150 years ago with the help of an enterprising Brit. In Fukuoka, he visits one of the Bullet Train's giant repair centres and in Hiroshima, he unravels what happened to its streetcar network after the world's first atomic bomb devastated the city.
